WinTieLoss 0.1.0

Compute Win–Tie–Loss Summary for Methods

win.tie.loss.compute.Rd

This function compares the performance of multiple methods across datasets by calculating the **Win–Tie–Loss (WTL)** summary. It performs all pairwise comparisons between methods based on their scores, counting how many times each method wins, ties, or loses relative to the others.

The function is useful in benchmarking and performance evaluation studies, where you want to summarize how often each method performs better or worse than the others according to a given metric (e.g., accuracy, RMSE, F1-score).

win.tie.loss.compute(data, measure.type)

Arguments

data

A `data.frame` containing the scores of different methods. - Columns represent methods. - Rows represent datasets or experimental runs. - NA values are replaced by 0.

measure.type

An integer (0 or 1) indicating the direction of optimization:

  • `1` – higher scores are better (wins if method1 > method2)

  • `0` – lower scores are better (wins if method1 < method2)

Value

A `data.frame` summarizing the number of wins, ties, and losses per method. It has the following columns:

  • `method` – the method name.

  • `win` – total number of pairwise wins.

  • `tie` – total number of pairwise ties.

  • `loss` – total number of pairwise losses.

Details

The function expects a data frame where: - Each **column** corresponds to a method. - Each **row** corresponds to a dataset, experiment, or observation.

Pairwise comparisons are performed for every combination of methods. NA values are replaced with 0 before computation.

If `measure.type = 1`, **higher values are better** (e.g., accuracy). If `measure.type = 0`, **lower values are better** (e.g., RMSE, error rate).

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
#--------------------------------------------------------------
# Example: Compute Win–Tie–Loss from random data
#--------------------------------------------------------------

# 1. Load example dataset
data_path <- "~/WinTieLoss/Data/random-data.csv"
data <- data.frame(read.csv(data_path))
data <- data[, -1]  # Remove first column (dataset names)

# 2. Define measure type
# Suppose lower is better (e.g., clp)
measure.type <- 0

# 3. Compute Win–Tie–Loss summary
results <- win.tie.loss.compute(data = data, measure.type = measure.type)

# 4. Sort by method
methods.names <- colnames(data)
results$method <- factor(results$method, levels = methods.names)
results <- results[order(results$method), ]

# 5. Print results
print(results)

# 6. Save to CSV
output_path <- "~/WinTieLoss/Results/wtl-summary.csv"
write.csv(results, output_path, row.names = FALSE)
} # }
